Responsive layout grid

Columns, gutters, and margins

The responsive column grid is made up of columns, gutters, and margins, providing a convenient layout structure for elements within the body region. Components, imagery, and text align with the column grid to create a logical and consistent layout experience across screen sizes and orientations.

As the size of the body region grows or shrinks, the number of grid columns changes in response.

Breakpoints

A breakpoint defines the screen size at which a layout will adapt to best fit content and conform to responsive layout requirements. A breakpoint range informs how a screen adjusts to fit its size and orientation.

Material's breakpoint range considers the number of columns and margins, as well as the gutter values used in a layout. Â 

When using window sizes, an app can alter the number of layout columns to be used inside of a grid container as needed.

Material measurements

To ensure that Material Design layouts are visually balanced, most measurements align to 8dp, which corresponds to both spacing and the overall layout. Components are sized in 8dp increments, ensuring a consistent visual rhythm across each screen.

Smaller elements, such as icons, can align to a 4dp grid, while typography can fall on a 4dp baseline grid. This allows each lineâs typographic baseline to be spaced in increments of 4dp from a neighbor.

Layout regions

Layout regions are the foundation for interactive experiences. They consist of elements and components that share similar functions. Layout regions can also group smaller containers, such as cards or lists.

Large screen layouts include 3 main regions

  1. Navigation
  2. App bar
  3. Body

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Navigation region

The navigation region holds navigational components and elements such as the navigation drawer or navigation rail. It helps users navigate between destinations in an app or to access important actions.Â 

The navigation region maintains a consistent width of 360dp when expanded and 80dp when collapsed.

If a layoutâs margin is less than 48dp (screen widths 600-839dp, for example) the width of the body region can decrease in size to accommodate the navigation region.

contentChunks.footer: When using a navigation drawer, the body region (2) can be condensed to accommodate the navigation region (1).
contentChunks.altText: A tablet layout diagram showing two parts, the navigation region on the right hand one-third of the screen and the body region on the left hand two-thirds of the screen.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Body region

The body region is used for displaying most of the content in an app. It typically contains components such as lists, cards, buttons, and images.

The body region uses scaling values for the following three parameters:

  • Vertical and horizontal dimensions
  • Number of columns
  • Margins

At extra small breakpoints, margins have a value of 16dp. As the layout increases in size, the body section expands relative to the width of the screen. Upon reaching the first breakpoint (small; 600dp wide) the margins increase to 32dp.

When the width of the body reaches 840dp, margins increase to a maximum width of 200dp. After this maximum width is met, the body region once again becomes responsive, continuing to scale horizontally.
Containment

Containment is a method for connecting related elements that share a context, such as an image and a caption. Itâs a form of grouping that visually relates elements in a view and establishes boundaries to distinguish unrelated elements.

Implicit and explicit containment

Containment methods include implicit and explicit grouping of content. When composing elements or components that contain text, ensure that each container uses responsive dimensions so that text can easily scale and remain readable.

Implicit containment is a method of grouping content or elements that may not appear to have edges but manage to impart an implied boundary or container. Use implicit containment to group content and subtly lend cohesion to several elements.

Explicit containment methods show container boundaries and clarify that an item can be tapped. Explicit containment can also be used to emphasize something. Explicit containment methods include adding an outline or elevation level to a group of related elements. For example, creating a card from an image and its supporting text unites the two elements by defining them as a group through the cardâs outlined boundary.

Container properties

As containers scale to adapt to different screen sizes, their position and alignment should also be considered.

Containers and their elements can align left, right, or center as the parent container scales. They can also have a fixed position, as seen with FABs or navigation drawers.

Component adaptation
Component adaptation describes changes in visual presentation (padding, size, layout, or alignment), or switching out one component for different one to better suit the device size and use case.

contentChunks.footer: Left: Folded portrait view; Right: Unfolded landscape view shows a card that fills a larger container and the banner shifts to be right-aligned.
contentChunks.altText: A side-by-side comparison of the same app on a folded device and on an unfolded screen taking up more space.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
When scaling components or layout containers, consider how their position and alignment should scale. Internal elements can be anchored to the left, right, or center as a parent container scales. Internal elements can also maintain fixed positions, as seen in the example of a floating action button (FAB) within a navigation drawer.

A componentâs internal composition should accommodate the ergonomic needs of the device on which it appears. For example, a horizontally-oriented card on a mobile device can become more square-shaped on larger screens. This change can lend more prominence to imagery or allow room for larger type styles that enhance readability. In the case of an icon button, the icon and text label within the button can remain anchored to each other, remaining centered within the button as it scales horizontally.

Visual presentation

Â Visual presentation is the most common method of adaptation. This type of adaptation effects the scale and placement of content and objects on screen, as well as their relationship to each other. For example, a text list on a mobile device can have adjusted margins, vertical spacing, or density to better fit larger screens like tablets.

Component swapping

Â As a layout changes across screen sizes, components with similar functions can also be exchanged. This makes it possible to adjust a layout for large-scale changes to the ergonomic and functional qualities of an interface.

Â For example, a bottom navigation bar can swap with a navigation rail on tablets or a navigation drawer on larger screens.

contentChunks.footer: Components can switch types. For example, a full-screen dialog (1) on mobile can be exchanged with a basic dialog (2) on larger screens. This component change maintains the function of the dialog, while also making use of screen space in a way that preserves a userâs context by revealing underlying content.
contentChunks.altText: A side-by-side view of a mobile UI with a full screen dialog on the left and a landscape mode tablet on the left using a basic dialog centered on the screen with a scrim showing more content is still semi-visible while the dialog is active.

The arrangement of components in a layout can also adjust with changes in screen sizes. This adaptation occurs either by repositioning the component or concealing/revealing information based on available screen space.

Reveal elements

Parts of the UI that are hidden on smaller screens can be revealed when adapting for a larger breakpoint's additional space.

Mouse and cursor interactions

When an external mouse input device is used, a mouse cursor should be shown, regardless of the form factor of the device.Â 

A mouse may be connected to tablets, laptops, phones, foldables, and more. On some devices, it's possible to use an external input device simultaneously with touch input.Â
